author: By Anand Giridharadas
title: The Epic Life of the Woman Behind Roe v. Wade
description: “The Family Roe,” by Joshua Prager, is a nuanced, deeply reported portrait of Norma McCorvey, known to most Americans as Jane Roe, the plaintiff in the case that won abortion rights for U.S. women.
content: THE FAMILY ROE An American Story By Joshua Prager
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Amy Klobuchar says she was treated for breast cancer.
description: “At this point my doctors believe that my chances of developing cancer again are no greater than the average person,” the senator wrote in a post on Medium.
content: Senator Amy Klobuchar said Thursday that she had been diagnosed and treated this year for breast cancer, and that her doctors said in August that her treatment had been successful.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eleanor Barkhorn
title: Which Values Should Guide America’s Laws?
description: Reflections on Texas’ abortion law.
content: This article also appears in the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it in your inbox each weekday morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The T List: Five Things We Recommend This Week
description: A Marcel Breuer doc, a purse that’s a pouch — and more.
content: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we share things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: ‘No Responders Left Behind’ Review: Heroes Need Heroes Too
description: John Feal works tirelessly as an advocate for rescuers injured or sickened in the events of Sept. 11, 2001, and their aftermath.
content: In “No Responders Left Behind,” John Feal is a kind of action hero — political action, that is. This documentary by Rob Lindsay follows Feal’s tenacious efforts to obtain government health benefits and compensation for the thousands of rescuers with illnesses and injuries from working on Sept. 11, 2001, and beyond.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: New York Fashion Week: Day 2
description: When a coat with a hole on its back becomes something more.
content: Fashion Week is back in full force, and there’s a lot to see. Blink (or scroll too fast on Instagram) and you’ll miss the details: tiny bags, tall shoes, feathered hats, leather capes and diamond dog collars. Every day we’ll spotlight one thing we saw on the runways that delighted or mystified us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Ngo
title: Skilled Workers Are Scarce, Posing a Challenge for Biden’s Infrastructure Plan
description: One estimate says the bill would add $1.4 trillion to the U.S. economy over eight years, but without enough workers, efforts to strengthen roads and public transit could be set back.
content: WASHINGTON — The infrastructure bill that President Biden hopes to get through Congress is supposed to create jobs and spur projects for companies like Anchor Construction, which specializes in repairing aging bridges and roadways in the nation’s capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘Azor’ Review: A World on Fire, Discreetly
description: In this low-key shocker set in Argentina in 1980, a Swiss banker travels through a world that he doesn’t seem to know is ablaze.
content: Tendrils of menace creep through the unnerving drama “Azor,” snaking through every room and scene. It’s 1980 and a Swiss private banker and his wife are traveling through Argentina, taking in the sights while he tries to clean up a mess left by a missing colleague. Danger is everywhere — people have disappeared, are disappearing — though you wouldn’t necessarily know it from the mansions they visit, where the Swiss interlopers exchange pleasantries with the Buenos Aires elite, some of whom voice vague warnings. Others just smile knowingly, betraying their loyalties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: In ‘What Happened?,’ a Questioning Farewell to Rhinebeck
description: In the last installment in his 12-play series, Richard Nelson asks how his characters, and the theater, got where they are today.
content: Kate, a woman in her late 60s, sits alone at a weather-beaten table, the clutter of a cauliflower lasagna mostly cleared and her dinner companions now out for the evening. Together, they have spent most of the last two hours talking about Rose, Kate’s wife, who six months earlier, while dying of ovarian cancer, was killed by Covid-19 instead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: You Are Invited to Our Wedding. Kindly Tell Us Your Vaccination Status.
description: As the busy fall wedding season arrives, the Delta variant is forcing guests and couples to conform to new rules of etiquette.
content: Asking wedding guests to leave their children at home used to be among the thornier requests a couple could make.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: New Chapter in Richmond as Lee Statue Comes Down
description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, September 9, 2021.
content: “I would have thought somebody would blow up Richmond first before anyone would have let that happen. It’s a modern-day miracle.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Spencer Ackerman
title: How Sept. 11 Gave Us Jan. 6
description: The domestic attack on the Capitol was a direct result of the war on terror.
content: Ever since insurrectionists invaded the Capitol, we’ve heard that Jan. 6 closed a chapter in American history. No longer should America’s most threatening enemies be understood as foreign — a euphemism for Muslim — but instead as domestic, a euphemism for primarily white Americans on the far right. “The ‘post-9/11’ era, where our greatest threats to national security were external, is over,” said Representative Elissa Slotkin, Democrat of Michigan and a former C.I.A. and Pentagon official.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Live Panel for Students: The Post-9/11 Generation
description: How did 9/11 shape the generation that grew up in its aftermath? Register for our panel on Sept. 30 and invite your students to share their perspectives.
content: Today’s middle and high school students were born after Sept. 11, 2001, yet they grew up in a world shaped by the attacks and their aftermath. What does Sept. 11 mean to the post-9/11 generation?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: Riz Ahmed Is Breaking Hollywood’s ‘Ethnicity Handcuffs’
description: The actor and musician has broken out past Hollywood’s stereotypical portrayals of Muslims. But does it matter if he’s the exception to the rule?
content: Since 9/11, and even before, Hollywood’s portrayal of Muslims has emboldened inaccurate stereotypes of dangerous villains or jihadist terrorists. In addition to misrepresenting Muslims, the industry has also arguably underrepresented this population — one U.S.C. study found Muslims represented 1.6 percent of speaking roles in recent major films. Actor, musician and activist Riz Ahmed is challenging this status quo in a career that has included playing a guileless assistant struggling to make ends meet in “Nightcrawler” and a drummer who loses his hearing in the film “Sound of Metal.” In 2021, he became the first Muslim to be nominated for a best actor Oscar — an accolade he found “bittersweet.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Marczynski
title: A Writer’s Deathbed Portrait of Francis Bacon
description: Max Porter’s new novel imagines the last days of a painter who shares his obsession with mortality.
content: Max Porter is a writer who’s spent a long time thinking about death. “I would say I’m a death-obsessed, or a mortality-preoccupied, person,” he said recently in a video interview from his home in Bath, England.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: What Is ‘American Fashion’ Now?
description: As New York Fashion Week begins and the Met Gala returns, it’s time to confront the question of who gets to define a nation’s style — and whether anyone can.
content: In less than a week, on Sept. 13, as the sun sets over Central Park, the great and the good and the very, very glamorous will sweep up the marble steps of the Metropolitan Museum of Art for the party of the year, otherwise known as the Met Gala, for the first time since the pandemic began.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Foreign Terrorists Have Never Been Our Biggest Threat
description: By 9/11, domestic extremism was already on the rise.
content: It may seem like a terrible thing to say, but a fair number of people — especially in the news media — are nostalgic about the months that followed 9/11. Some pundits openly pine for the sense of national unity that, they imagine, prevailed in the aftermath of the terrorist attack. More subtly, my sense is that many long for the days when the big threat to America seemed to come from foreign fanatics, not homegrown political extremists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Sam Cunningham Dies at 71; Fostered Integration on the Football Field
description: As one of three Black players in the U.S.C. backfield, he led the team to a stunning win in 1970 over Coach Bear Bryant’s all-white Alabama. He would go on to star for the New England Patriots.
content: Sam Cunningham, a fullback for the integrated University of Southern California football team that in 1970 trounced Coach Bear Bryant’s all-white Alabama squad, died on Tuesday at his home in Inglewood, Calif. He was 71.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: ​North Korea Forgoes the Usual Muscle-Flexing in a Military Parade
description: The parade, which marked the government’s 73rd anniversary, was seen as a celebration of those who have borne the brunt of the regime’s effort to rebuild the economy amid sanctions and the pandemic.
content: SEOUL — ​North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, attended a national predawn military parade on Thursday, but skipped the opportunity to raise tensions with the United States through a fiery speech or the display of long-range ballistic missiles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jean Valentine and Reginald Dwayne Betts
title: Poem: I came to you
description: From a poet who was always looking for and singing the names of others.
content: When Jean Valentine died on Dec. 29, 2020, America lost one of its most generous poets. Just days ago I was going through the many letters my friends from prison have sent me. And somehow within the mix was a letter from Jean. She wondered if I had the names of some young poets she should be checking for. I wish I remembered whose name I gave her, if anyone’s. But maybe it doesn’t matter; maybe for us poets, it only matters that someone is asking if we exist. Jean Valentine was a poet always looking for and singing the names of others. Selected by Reginald Dwayne Betts
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: Loveland, Colo., to Pay $3 Million to Woman With Dementia Who Was Arrested
description: The settlement comes more than a year after Karen Garner, then 73, was grabbed by a police officer and flung to the ground for allegedly shoplifting from a Walmart.
content: A city in Colorado will pay a $3 million settlement to a 74-year-old woman with dementia whom police officers threw to the ground last year and handcuffed after she was suspected of shoplifting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘The Card Counter’ Review: A Gambler’s Existential Solitaire
description: Oscar Isaac, Tiffany Haddish and Willem Dafoe star in the latest head trip from Paul Schrader, a story about betting on life.
content: A man sits writing in a room, alone in his head, alone in the world. We hear his words, his thoughts, in a voice-over that’s a portal to his reality. It’s an intimate, unmodulated voice, and what he says is often unremarkable to the point of banality. Yet something troubles the man which, in turn, troubles you. He may be a good man gone wrong or a bad one gone right; the only thing certain is that he jumped out of the head of Paul Schrader.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Spencer Bokat-Lindell
title: Do We Need Booster Shots More than the World Needs Vaccines?
description: As rich countries ponder the marginal utility of third doses, billions of people around the world are still waiting for their first.
content: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Tuesdays and Thursdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: languid
description: This word has appeared in 58 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘Dogs’ Review: Fish Out of Water
description: A city boy inherits land used by the Mafia in this unoriginal neo-western crime thriller from Romania.
content: The city boy Roman (Dragos Bucur) is lured into the Romanian outback when he inherits 550 hectares of land from his recently deceased grandfather, a local “godfather” figure not terribly unlike those popularized by Mario Puzo. Though Roman arrives with the intention of quickly selling the miserable property for some extra cash, his sojourn is upended when a group of thugs headed by the smug, sinister Samir (Vlad Ivanov) come to play.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: New York Fashion Week Is Back
description: Featuring a special appearance by Gov. Kathy Hochul, upcycling and ideas from Proenza Schouler, Prabal Gurung and Collina Strada on what to wear.
content: You know something has changed when the biggest celebrity at a fashion show is not Gina Gershon or Nicky Hilton or “Riverdale’s” Madelaine Petsch but Kathy Hochul, the new governor of New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Kehinde Wiley Portrait Inspired by ‘The Blue Boy’ Will Be Unveiled in October
description: The Huntington commissioned the artist, best known for his portrait of Barack Obama, to create a large-scale painting in response to the Thomas Gainsborough masterpiece.
content: Growing up in Los Angeles, the artist Kehinde Wiley was inspired by the beauty, wealth, glory and power of the Grand Manner portraits of men in regal poses at the Huntington in San Marino, Calif., though he was struck by one frustrating omission: Where were the subjects of color?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Finn Cohen
title: ‘Muhammad Ali’ Explores the Many Layers of ‘the Greatest’
description: A new four-part documentary series by Ken Burns paints a sweeping portrait of a man whose life intersected with many of modern America’s most profound changes.
content: One day in the mid-1990s, Ken Burns had a cold while he was in Los Angeles to raise money for his next documentary. He ducked into a coffee shop for some hot tea, and after paying, one of the 20th century’s most ardent historians turned from the counter and locked eyes with perhaps its most towering icon. Muhammad Ali was sitting in a booth nearby. The two men stared at each other silently for longer than most strangers would — celebrities or not.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: Dear Colleagues, Will You Please Mask Up?
description: A reader asks about navigating an office where vaccination is not required.
content: My employer doesn’t require masks in the office, and most people don’t wear them — even in meeting rooms where social distancing is impossible. Still, I wear a mask, and I’d feel better if my colleagues did too. We returned to the office in June, before the Delta variant became widespread in my state and Covid infection rates were low. I’m vaccinated, but the vaccination rate is low in my area. (And our employer says we shouldn’t ask co-workers if they are vaccinated.) Is there a way to ask co-workers to wear masks in the office? I have young children who aren’t eligible for vaccination, and I want to keep them safe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: U.S. states with low vaccination rates see sharp spikes in children with Covid-19.
description: The number of children admitted to the hospital in the United States with Covid-19 has risen to the highest levels reported to date. Nearly 30,000 of them entered hospitals in August.
content: The number of children admitted to the hospital in the United States with Covid-19 has risen to the highest levels reported to date. Nearly 30,000 of them entered hospitals in August.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roberta Smith
title: After the Storm, Philip Guston for Real
description: Compensating for a postponed museum retrospective, an exciting gallery show revisits the painter’s late figurative style.
content: Hauser & Wirth, the gallery that has represented the estate of Philip Guston since 2015, has leapt unto the breach. In lieu of “Philip Guston Now,” the enormous, widely anticipated retrospective set to tour to four museums on both sides of the Atlantic that was abruptly postponed last September, Hauser & Wirth has mounted a powerful exhibition of 18 of the late paintings that are the crowning achievement of Abstract Expressionism’s greatest apostate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kolomatsky
title: New Apartment Construction Perseveres in 2021
description: The number of new units expected to open has kept pace with that of prior years, despite the pandemic.
content: The problems that have challenged home buyers during the pandemic have been well documented, with skyrocketing prices, low inventory and bidding wars topping the list. New home construction has also faced difficulties, with the closure of government agencies that issued permits and interruptions in the supply chain of construction materials (lumber in particular).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: Two Scientific Journals Retract Articles Involving Chinese DNA Research
description: The rare retractions come after several scientists raised questions about how Chinese researchers obtained the full consent of their Uyghur subjects.
content: Two respected scientific journals have retracted two articles that relied on the DNA samples of Uyghurs in western China after questions were raised about whether the subjects had provided their full consent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Sept. 15, 2021
description: How did the pandemic change how we spend our free time?
content: These graphs show the average time not in school or work spent per day (in minutes), by age, for May through December 2019 versus the same period in 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Wolf
title: On London Stages, High Ambitions and Mixed Results
description: In “Rockets and Blue Lights” and “Once Upon a Time in Nazi Occupied Tunisia,” British playwrights make grand gestures. Sometimes too grand.
content: LONDON — It seems reasonable to expect fireworks from a play called “Rockets and Blue Lights,” a vivid title for an overstuffed, if intriguing, drama with no shortage of things to say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: U.S. vaccine mandate covers two-thirds of workers.
content: President Biden on Thursday used the full force of his presidency to get two-thirds of the American work force vaccinated against the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: What Did Best-Selling Illustrators Doodle While Daydreaming in School?
description: Three artists open up about the influences that led them to pick up pen, pencil and paintbrush.
content: O.G. INFLUENCERS We all know how illustrations from iconic picture books can imprint themselves on our imaginations with the indelibility of an important memory. Close your eyes and you might be able to see a gaggle of girls in yellow coats swarming Miss Clavel in Ludwig Bemelmans’s “Madeline,” or amphibious buddies lounging on a log on the cover of Arnold Lobel’s “Frog and Toad Are Friends.” Who are the artists behind the latest generation of much-loved, well-thumbed stories, and what shapes their work? I checked in with three best-selling illustrators to find out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Patchett
title: Sometimes the Luck Is in the Fall
description: Ann Patchett finds that misfortune in small doses can cast a glittering light on the rest of life.
content: On a Sunday morning in the middle of July, I woke up tired. Who knows why? Maybe, like the dog, I had spent the night chasing rabbits in my sleep. I gave serious consideration to skipping my morning exercises (hadn’t the rabbits been enough?), but then decided to push ahead on the belief that an adherence to routine helps more often than it hurts. Surely gold medalist Sunisa Lee had been tired in Tokyo that morning, but she went flying through the air all the same.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Imbler
title: A Swirling Vortex Is No Match for This Deep-Sea Sponge
description: A new paper finds a glass sponge has the power to eliminate destructive vortices that are created when fluid moves around a blunt object.
content: At the bottom of the Pacific Ocean, cylindrical clusters of the glass sponge Euplectella aspergillum jut upward like skyscrapers in the deep sea. Some house tiny shrimp, to whom an 11-inch sponge is essentially a high-rise. And the sponge’s glass skeleton is certainly a feat of architecture, comprising a geometric latticework that gives the sponge the illusion of being wrapped in lace. Yet it is enduringly sturdy, able to stay rooted in the sea floor and weather currents without snapping or splintering.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Stays Execution in Dispute Over Pastor’s Role in Death Chamber
description: The ruling was the latest in a string of decisions on the role that spiritual advisers may play in death row inmates’ final moments.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Wednesday stayed the execution of a Texas inmate whose request that his pastor be able to touch and pray aloud with him in the death chamber had been rejected by prison authorities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Richtel
title: F.D.A. Delays Decision on Juul’s E-Cigarettes but Orders Others Off the Market
description: The agency had faced a Sept. 9 deadline to decide whether the products could stay on the market but said it needed more time to review evidence.
content: The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday put off a long-anticipated ruling on whether Juul Labs and other major e-cigarette companies could continue to sell their products in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Fed Officials’ Trading Draws Outcry, and Fuels Calls for Accountability
description: Central bank regional presidents traded securities in markets in which Fed choices mattered in 2020. Here’s why critics find that troubling.
content: Federal Reserve officials traded stocks and other securities in 2020, a year in which the central bank took emergency steps to prop up financial markets and prevent their collapse — raising questions about whether the Fed’s ethics standards have become too lax as its role has vastly expanded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes and Daniel E. Slotnik
title: U.S. virus cases are more than ten times too high, Fauci says.
description: “The endgame is to suppress the virus,” Dr. Anthony S. Fauci told Axios. “Right now, we’re still in pandemic mode.”
content: Coronavirus infections are more than ten times higher than they need to be in order to end the pandemic, Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, the nation’s top infectious disease doctor, told the political news site Axios.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: California’s Recall Election Is Broken
description: Voters should choose “no” on the recall question and the state should look to reform the process.
content: California’s process for recalling its governor is so broken, some Democratic strategists are encouraging a vote for a Republican former San Diego mayor because “he’s not insane.” Millions of mail-in ballots were already cast before the state even released a list of qualified write-in candidates to potentially replace the sitting governor, Gavin Newsom, a Democrat, leaving voters to choose from a list of 46 mostly gadflies and wannabes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By George Gene Gustines
title: Spider-Man’s First Comic Brings $3.6 Million, Likely a Record
description: The Amazing Fantasy No. 15 from 1962 leaps past Superman to sell for what is believed to be the highest price for a comic book.
content: Spider-Man has just reached a new level of amazing. A copy of the Marvel hero’s first comic book appearance sold at Heritage Auctions on Thursday for $3.6 million. The comic book — Amazing Fantasy No. 15 from 1962, when it sold for 12 cents — was in near perfect condition. With this sale, Spider-Man leaps ahead of Superman for what is believed to be the highest price for a comic book.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: A Big Delta Unknown
description: Is the variant more severe than earlier versions of the virus? We look at the latest data.
content: It remains perhaps the most important unanswered question about the Delta variant: Does it cause more severe illness than earlier versions of the Covid virus — or equally severe symptoms in the average infected person (while clearly being more contagious)?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Biden Administration Moves to Protect Alaska’s Bristol Bay
description: The bay, home to a key sockeye salmon fishery, sits atop a massive gold and copper deposit, pitting environmentalists against mining companies.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration on Thursday took the first steps that would allow it to begin the process of protecting Alaska’s pristine Bristol Bay, one of the world’s most valuable sockeye salmon fisheries that also sits atop massive copper and gold deposits long coveted by mining companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: Review: In ‘Scenes From a Marriage,’ a Couple Unhappy in the Same Way
description: Hagai Levi’s adaptation echoes the passion of Bergman’s original, but it doesn’t make the case for a new version.
content: If the near future of TV is endless reinterpretations and remakes of intellectual property — more superheroes, more “Star Wars,” a new “Fantasy Island,” a new “Wonder Years” —perhaps it was inevitable that the trend would turn to one of the 20th century’s enduring superbrands: Ingmar Bergman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘Dating & New York’ Review: Texts and the City
description: A winning cast helps sell a too-familiar premise about commitment-phobic millennials.
content: “Dating & New York” is consciously framed as a modern fairy tale: It opens with a set of watercolor paintings that portray the city in clean, soft textures and a voice-over informing us that “once upon a time” there, two millennials were cursed with the “paradox of choice.” Wendy (Francesca Reale) and Milo (Jaboukie Young-White) connect through a dating app, meet once and then ghost each other. When they finally rendezvous again, Wendy has drawn up a written contract for a “best friends with benefits” arrangement. The two embark on a relationship they refuse to acknowledge as such.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: Small businesses can get $2 million disaster loans, with more time to pay them back.
description: Those that took smaller Economic Injury Disaster Loans will be able to apply for increases.
content: Small businesses seeking cash to help them weather the pandemic can now borrow up to $2 million from the federal government, after the Biden administration said on Thursday that it would lift a $500,000 cap on disaster relief loans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley
title: Incendiary Essay Ignites Guessing Over Xi’s Plans for China
description: After Communist Party websites shared Li Guangman’s fierce denunciation of private corporations, contention broke out over whether leaders share his views.
content: For years, Li Guangman, a retired Chinese newspaper editor, wrote in obscurity, firing off attack after attack at chic celebrities and celebrated tycoons whom he accused of betraying the sturdy socialist values of Mao. Few outside of China’s fervent but narrow world of Maoist leftists read them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siddhartha Mitter
title: At Future Fair, Discovering Emerging and Undersung Players
description: The new art fair wants to be a “change agent” with more collaboration, global locations and a hyperlocal New York scene.
content: New York’s newest art fair, Future Fair, intends to serve as a change agent — toward “an art market where people are collaborating and co-curating,” said Rachel Mijares Fick, who co-founded it with Rebeca Laliberte.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor J. Blue, Sami Sahak, Lara Jakes and Eric Nagourney
title: First Flight From Kabul Is Hailed as Positive Step Amid Troubling Signs
description: A passenger jet’s departure on Thursday was the first foreign flight out of Afghanistan since the U.S. evacuation ended. But thousands who want to leave remain stuck.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — Ten days after the chaotic evacuation of Afghanistan came to an end, a lone jetliner lifted off from Kabul’s airport on Thursday, the first international passenger flight since American forces ended their 20-year presence in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Our Children Will Never Know the Innocence We Knew
description: Sept. 11 changed us.
content: After the attacks on the World Trade Center, Americans — and particularly New Yorkers — were told that we needed to go about our lives as we normally would to demonstrate to the terrorists that they hadn’t won.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green
title: Biden calls on states to implement vaccine requirements in schools.
description: He is also requiring vaccinations for teachers and other employees of schools run by federal agencies.
content: President Biden on Thursday amplified calls for states to take more aggressive measures to keep children in school amid surging coronavirus cases, calling on governors to require vaccinations for all school employees and for districts to implement more regular testing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Rothenberg
title: At U.S. Open, Novak Djokovic Moves One Step Closer to Grand Slam
description: After dropping the first set, the world No. 1 smoothly beat sixth-seeded Matteo Berrettini, 5-7, 6-2, 6-2, 6-3, to advance to the semifinals against Alexander Zverev.
content: The U.S. Open has waited 52 years for a man to have a chance at winning the Grand Slam, so what’s a few extra hours?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Vaccination Mandates Are an American Tradition. So Is the Backlash.
description: The roots of U.S. vaccine mandates predate both the U.S. and vaccines.
content: Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Steinmetz and Jay Massacret
title: For Fall, a New American Gothic
description: With long, layered silhouettes and raw textures like wool and denim, this season’s fashion revives — and reimagines — the pastoral looks of eras past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teo Bugbee
title: ‘Kate’ Review: Lost in Assassination
description: Mary Elizabeth Winstead plays a vengeful contract killer in this predictable thriller.
content: The thriller “Kate” is an undistinguished action film that makes a hero of a hit woman. Kate (Mary Elizabeth Winstead), guided by her wily handler, Varrick (Woody Harrelson), has been a professional since adolescence. Her only rule is to never kill in front of a child. Naturally — this being a relatively unimaginative plot — Kate betrays her principles within the first five minutes of the movie, murdering a yakuza gang member in front of his daughter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: President Biden is expected to impose new vaccination mandates in a speech on Thursday.
description: White House officials said that Mr. Biden would also detail initiatives meant to pressure private businesses, federal agencies and schools.
content: President Biden is expected on Thursday to impose new vaccination mandates as part of a broad plan to put pressure on private businesses, federal agencies and schools to enact stricter vaccination and testing policies as the Delta variant continues its spread across the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Sept. 9, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Sept. 9, 2021.
content: An article on Tuesday about an 11-year prison sentence handed to Maria Kolesnikova, a leading Belarus opposition leader, misstated her status in last year’s presidential election. She was active in the campaign of Svetlana Tikhanovskaya, but was not a presidential candidate herself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Chen
title: Dragon Boat Racing, Booming in Popularity, Confronts Abuse Case
description: The on-again, off-again prosecution of a leading coach has divided the racing community and raised questions about safeguards in the sport.
content: For the last three decades, dragon boat racing has surged in popularity around the world. Former rowers have switched to paddling and represented their countries in international races. Corporate and government employees have participated in community races. Young Asian Americans, buoyed by cultural pride, have dominated some rosters, especially in New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Medina, Shawn Hubler and Jill Cowan
title: Biden to campaign for Newsom in California on Monday.
description: The president’s visit will add another volley of national Democratic firepower to the governor’s effort to beat back a Republican-led effort to recall him.
content: President Biden will travel to California on Monday to campaign for Gov. Gavin Newsom, adding yet another volley of national Democratic firepower to the governor’s effort to beat back a Republican-led effort to recall him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Samantha Bee Blasts Supreme Court for Allowing the Texas Abortion Ban
description: The “Full Frontal” host wasn’t happy about the state’s law, which outlaws abortion after six weeks, or the high court’s decision not to block it.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: ‘Small Engine Repair’ Review: Of Mechanics and Men
description: John Pollono directs and stars in an adaptation of his play that adds depth to the original text but also struggles in its translation from stage to screen.
content: What happens in Manch-Vegas stays in Manch-Vegas. Just ask the men from “Small Engine Repair,” an adaptation of the play of the same name by the actor and playwright John Pollono. The film, which Pollono also directs, provides more depth than the original but still flounders in the translation from stage to screen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Zornosa
title: 7 Events in New York Honoring 9/11
description: On Saturday, performances and memorials around the city and online will mark the 20th anniversary of the attacks. Here’s how to find them.
content: Twenty years after four coordinated terrorist attacks by Al Qaeda killed 2,977 people — 2,753 of them at ground zero in New York City — the nation and the city remember. They remember through dance, music, museums, TV specials and light beamed into the sky.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Hodgman
title: Judge John Hodgman on the King-Size Bed
description: A husband wants to convert the living room so he and his wife can sleep on a bigger mattress.
content: Alan writes: My wife and I share a one-bedroom apartment in Vancouver. She has always wanted a king-size bed, but our bedroom is too narrow. I suggested we convert our large living room. She says that’s unnatural. But I’d like to treat my queen to a king.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dina Litovsky and Jake Nevins
title: The Girls of Clearview High Are Back on the Field
description: For the defending New Jersey field-hockey state champions, last year was a season of frustration and loss — and this year’s tryouts are a chance to rebuild
content: If the guiding spirits of high school sports are competition, fellowship and common purpose, the 2020-21 school year brought challenges to them all. Close-knit teams, accustomed to the physical camaraderie of the locker room or the huddle, had to keep their distance socially; coaches, used to the normal pattern of practices and games, found themselves canceling sessions, posting workouts online and doing their best to send encouraging emails to their players. In some cases, entire seasons were called off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Katie Rogers
title: New vaccine requirements apply to a broad range of the national work force.
description: President Biden cannot require all Americans to get vaccinated; in the United States, vaccinations are the province of the states.
content: President Biden’s federal employee mandate, announced Thursday, will apply to employees of the executive branch, including the White House and all federal agencies and members of the armed services — a work force that numbers more than four million — but not to those who work for Congress or the federal court system, according to White House officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Serge Schmemann
title: I Wrote the Lead Times Article on 9/11. Here’s What Still Grips Me.
description: After 20 years of war, a correspondent looks back.
content: Shortly after the attacks of Sept. 11, an English teacher in central Washington State assigned her eighth and ninth graders to write poems based on the lead article in The Times. The teacher, Tammy Grubb, said her intention was to give the students a way to process their feelings. The poems were posted in the school hallway and then, since my byline was on the article, Ms. Grubb sent them to me, 77 of them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: The Ways Bin Laden Won
description: Sept. 11 damaged America more than we realized 20 years ago.
content: I’ll always remember Sept. 11 as something that happened in the evening. At the time I was living in a town in northern India, and I watched the towers fall on a TV someone had dragged into the street. Because I was so far away, I’ll never know the terror people in New York and Washington felt on that day, the fear that more attacks were coming, that the epic disaster movies so popular during the bored ’90s had come viciously to life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamie Waters
title: Can a Man Wear Mules to Work?
description: For many men, gussied-up slippers are becoming a shoe for (almost) all occasions.
content: While some folks have sprinted out of lockdown keen to make up for lost time, a number of men have, er, shuffled back onto the streets. They are ambling, dawdling and slouching to lunches, drinks and work meetings, powered by insouciance rather than haste.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kara Swisher
title: What’s Wrong With Big Tech? Three Stanford Professors Think They Know.
description: “System Error,” by Rob Reich, Mehran Sahami and Jeremy M. Weinstein, explores the problems inherent in Silicon Valley’s hold on us.
content: SYSTEM ERRORWhere Big Tech Went Wrong and How We Can Reboot By Rob Reich, Mehran Sahami and Jeremy M. Weinstein
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Qatari jet carries more than 100 foreigners from Kabul.
description: Thursday’s flight to Doha was a major step in resolving an impasse that has left scores of foreigners stranded in Afghanistan.
content: The first passenger flight to leave Afghanistan since the frenzied U.S. military evacuation ended late last month arrived in Doha, the Qatari capital, on Thursday with more than 100 foreigners, including Americans, aboard, and Biden administration officials said they expected more such flights in coming days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Katie Rogers
title: Biden is requiring the vast majority of federal workers to get vaccinated or face disciplinary measures.
description: The move is part of a larger plan that officials said would cover two-thirds of all American workers.
content: President Biden on Thursday used the full force of his presidency to push two-thirds of American workers to get vaccinated against the coronavirus, reaching into the private sector to mandate that all companies with more than 100 workers require vaccination or weekly testing. Mr. Biden also moved to mandate shots for health care workers, federal contractors and the vast majority of federal workers, who could face disciplinary measures if they refuse
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valeriya Safronova
title: Eva Longoria Knows There’s Still Work to Do
description: The actress and entrepreneur has made inclusive hiring and civic engagement priorities throughout her career, including in her newest venture.
content: Eva Longoria, perhaps best known for her role in the TV show “Desperate Housewives,” has parlayed small-screen fame into a multipronged career. She has opened a production company, created a foundation, designed a clothing line and written a cookbook.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Capitol security fence to be reinstalled ahead of a rally to support Jan. 6 suspects.
description: The Capitol Police chief is calling for the complex to be fortified before the “Justice for J6” rally scheduled for Sept. 18.
content: Security officials at the Capitol plan to reinstall a fence around the complex ahead of a planned rally of Trump supporters next weekend called to demand the release of those arrested in connection with the Jan. 6 mob attack on Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: The Trumpeter Adam O’Farrill’s Art of Avoiding the Obvious
description: The son and grandson of Latin jazz royalty is releasing a new album with his quartet Stranger Days, and it’s their most melodically engaging yet.
content: If you pay close enough attention to jazz, Adam O’Farrill might have landed on your radar about a decade ago, when he was still an adolescent. His last name is immediately recognizable — his father and grandfather are Latin jazz royalty — but he stood apart even then, mostly by hanging back and letting his trumpet speak for itself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Fisher
title: As Abortion Rights Expand, the U.S. Joins a Handful of Telling Exceptions
description: Recent shifts on access to abortion suggest democracy and women’s rights go hand in hand — and that the inverse might be true as well.
content: The story of abortion rights in the 21st century can be seen in two world-shaking developments this past week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Farago
title: Why Art Struggled to Address the Horrors of 9/11
description: After the attacks, American culture became one of prohibitions. Then the Iraq War made it difficult to address Sept. 11 on its own terms.
content: Weeks after the towers fell, Jennifer Bartlett started painting. She had watched them collapse from her roof that September, and in her studio in the West Village she began depicting what almost no one wanted to depict, in her style of solid dots daubed into a grid of little squares. Toward the edges the dots are that distinctive cloudless blue, but most squares she overlaid with two dots, or three, the gray of the smoke superimposed on the red or saffron of the fireball. The dots became embers of exploded airplanes, or TV screen pixels (we had no smartphones then); they were papers raining down on the financial district and the Battery. Across two squares Bartlett placed a figure, stylized like in a cave painting, feet over head. A diver.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Palmer
title: Courtroom Reporting When You’re Not Quite in Court
description: Blurry sights, muffled sound. Covering the R. Kelly trial on a monitor in another room of the courthouse isn’t exactly ideal access, but we make do.
content: One day during R. Kelly’s trial in Brooklyn federal court, the priest who officiated the 1994 wedding of the R&B superstar and the 15-year-old singer Aaliyah was called to testify as a witness. He did so without stepping foot in New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: ‘Football Is Like Food’: Afghan Female Soccer Players Find a Home in Italy
description: Members of a team from Herat left behind the lives they had built in Afghanistan in hopes that they can build a future where they can play, and thrive.
content: AVEZZANO, Italy — Two days after Taliban fighters seized Herat, Afghanistan’s third-largest city, the Italian journalist Stefano Liberti received a message via Facebook: “Hi sir, we are in trouble. Can you help us?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Livingston and Haidee Findlay-Levin
title: Bold, Fall-Friendly Timepieces in Shades of Green
description: This batch of fresh-feeling options features emerald, juniper and pistachio dials, some with bands to match.
content: Green may usually be associated with spring but has lately been popping up on timepieces perfect for fall. It’s an unexpected flourish that adds a bit of freshness, whether you prefer a clean and unadorned look — see the Nomos Club Automatic — or a more embellished finish, as with the diamond-studded bezel of Patek Philippe’s Aquanaut Luce. The latter carries the shade through from its dial to its band, just like Hublot’s Big Bang Unico SORAI, while Omega’s Seamaster Aqua Terra sticks with a classic steel bracelet and H. Moser’s Pioneer Centre Seconds features a black textile strap.

title: The Elizabeth Holmes Courtroom Drama
description: Opening arguments in the long-awaited trial questioned whether the Theranos chief executive was knowingly deceptive or blindly ambitious.
content: The trial of Elizabeth Holmes began yesterday with opening arguments. Holmes, the founder and former C.E.O. of Theranos, a blood testing start-up, has been charged with 12 counts of wire fraud and conspiracy to commit wire fraud; if convicted, she faces up to 20 years in prison. Lawyers on both sides framed the debate set to dominate the trial: whether Holmes was knowingly cheating investors or blindly taken in by Silicon Valley’s “fake it ’til you make it culture” as well as by her former business and romantic partner Ramesh Balwani.

title: J Balvin Attempts to Reintroduce Himself on ‘Jose’
description: The Colombian star skips innovation and presents an impressionistic inventory of the sounds that established him as a global force on his sixth studio album.
content: If there is one figure in pop music who has perfected the language of feel-good cultural affirmation, it is J Balvin. For over a decade, the 36-year-old Colombian star has claimed he is on a mission to “change the perception of Latinos in music,” using his rainbow aesthetics, smooth reggaeton textures and radio-ready trap hits as ammunition.

title: Biden Administration Goes Bigger on Cutting Drug Prices

content: The Biden administration on Thursday endorsed an aggressive proposal to limit prices for prescription drugs, calling for the government to negotiate with drug makers on prices and applying those prices not just to Medicare but to all drug purchasers in the country.

title: Biden withdraws his nomination of David Chipman to lead the A.T.F.
description: The defeat is a major setback to the president’s plan to reduce gun violence, and it comes after his push to expand background checks on gun purchases stalled in Congress.
content: WASHINGTON — When President Biden nominated David Chipman to run the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives in March, he described it as an important step toward ending the “embarrassment” and “epidemic” of gun violence in America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: Trump produces a week of mixed messaging as he tries to attack Biden.
description: The former president has sought to project patriotism after the American retreat from Afghanistan — but he will also appear at a boxing match on the 9/11 anniversary, and he continues to stoke racial divisions.
content: Banished from social media and deprived of his national platform, former President Donald J. Trump has been clamoring for attention and trying to exploit the series of foreign and domestic crises that are testing the Biden administration.

title: Pinball Museum Will Auction 1,700 Arcade Games After Closing Its Doors
description: The Museum of Pinball in Banning, Calif., is closing because of financial difficulties, augmented by the pandemic. Its collection could be worth as much as $7 million.

author: By Jay Caspian Kang
title: Why SAT Test Prep Doesn’t Help Who You Might Think It Helps
description: The relationship between the use of standardized tests in college admissions and diversity on campus is far from clear.
content: In May of this year, the University of California Board of Regents, which makes decisions for a system that educates 280,000 students across 10 campuses, announced it would end the use of the SAT and ACT in the U.C. admissions process, effective immediately. This was a departure from a year before, when the regents, who had suspended the use of the test for Covid pandemic reasons, revealed a plan to phase out the tests over the next five years. But then a lawsuit got settled that forced the U.C. system to speed up the timeline and make the change permanent, with vague plans to begin using a customized test by 2025. (Those plans have been put on hold.) The initial, slower timeline should not be seen as a sign of reticence on the board’s part, however; when it voted in 2020 on whether to phase out the tests, the vote was 23-0.

title: Brazil’s President Bans Social Networks From Removing Some Posts
description: The new rules in Brazil appear to be the first national policy that restricts how tech companies can control their sites, analysts say.
content: President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil is temporarily banning social media companies from removing certain content, including his claims that the only way he’ll lose next year’s elections is if the vote is rigged — one of the most significant steps by a democratically elected leader to control what can be said on the internet.

content: Whitney Bartol, 17, a high school senior in Manhattan, can recite like a catechism Jennifer Aniston’s lifetime trajectory, from her television debut as Rachel on “Friends,” to her string of failed romances and recent turn as a flinty but flappable network anchor on “The Morning Show.”

author: By Aanya Wipulasena and Mujib Mashal
title: Sunil Perera, Outspoken King of Sri Lankan Baila Music, Is Dead at 68
description: The frontman of his family’s popular band combined the country’s unique, Latin-influenced sound with politically biting lyrics.
content: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — In the end, it was only appropriate that Sunil Perera, who had entertained generations of Sri Lankans on the radio and on the dance floor with his distinctive, Latin-fused tunes, would go out singing.

title: The Justice Dept. sues Texas over its new restrictive abortion law.
description: The move is the first major step by the Biden administration to confront the new law, the nation’s most restrictive in terms of abortion access.
content: The Justice Department sued Texas on Thursday over its recently enacted law that prohibits nearly all abortions in the state, the first significant step by the Biden administration to fight the nation’s most restrictive ban on abortion and a move that could once again put the statute before the Supreme Court.

content: Elizabeth McCann, a theater producer known for what one journalist called her “steel and wit” who in a dizzying four-decade career won nine Tony Awards, many of them as half of McCann & Nugent Productions, and gave New York audiences more than 60 Broadway productions, including such hits as “Equus,” “Amadeus” and “Les Liaisons Dangereuses,” died on Wednesday in the Bronx. content: THURSDAY PUZZLE — When I’m solving a crossword, I often find myself groaning at one of the many puns that are sure to appear in the grid.
