source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: In a new appeal, Kevin McCarthy asks the Supreme Court to end proxy voting in the House.
description: House Democrats have implemented special rules to allow for remote legislating during the pandemic. But Mr. McCarthy argues that the Constitution requires lawmakers to vote in person.
content: Representative Kevin McCarthy, Republican of California and the minority leader, asked the Supreme Court on Thursday to strike down the proxy voting system adopted by the House of Representatives last year to allow for remote legislating during the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Ford will stop making cars in India after losing $2 billion there over 10 years.
description: American automakers have long struggled to gain a foothold in India, where people tend to buy smaller vehicles.
content: Ford Motor will stop making cars at two plants in India, ending a long and costly effort to build a presence in one of the world’s largest emerging auto markets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels and Michael Gonchar
title: 10 Ways to Teach About 9/11 With The New York Times
description: Ideas for helping students think about how the Sept. 11 attacks have changed our nation and world.
content: Sept. 11, 2001, is one of those rare days that, if you ask most adults what they remember, they can tell you exactly where they were, whom they were with and what they were thinking. It is a day seared in memory. But for students who were born in a post-9/11 world and have grown up in the aftermath, it is complex history that needs to be remembered, taught and analyzed like any other historical event.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Inside Missouri’s ‘2nd Amendment Sanctuary’ Fight
description: A new law puts Missouri at the vanguard of states challenging federal authority on guns. It began as a backlash, and it has set off another.
content: OZARK, Mo. — Brad Cole is a fiery defender of the Second Amendment, a set-jawed lawman with a lacquered alligator head on his desk, a Smith & Wesson .357 Magnum on his hip and a signed picture of himself with former President Donald J. Trump on his office wall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winnie Hu
title: An Urban Archive Was Lost on 9/11. This Agency Is Trying to Rebuild It.
description: The Port Authority, which was headquartered in the World Trade Center and lost 84 employees, is collecting artifacts with the help of retirees.
content: A big brass model of the tunneling machine that carved out the Holland Tunnel was displayed in the engineering department.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘Language Lessons’ Review: Who’s Zooming Who?
description: Natalie Morales and Mark Duplass play a teacher and student in this found-footage story of a long-distance friendship.
content: Adam, who lives in a big house in the Oakland hills, has a plunge pool, a sauna, and a husband who buys him, as a surprise birthday gift, a series of 100 weekly online sessions with a Spanish teacher. The teacher is Cariño, who lives with her mother in Costa Rica. Over the course of their work together, she and Adam cross the boundary from pedagogy into something deeper.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Airlines end a strong summer, but the Delta variant stifles momentum.
description: United Airlines and Delta Air Lines said they expected the recovery to resume once coronavirus cases peaked.
content: Airlines ended the traditional summer travel season on a high note, but hopes for the fall have dimmed as employers delay office reopenings and the Delta variant of the coronavirus has eroded sales and driven up cancellations in recent weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia Heyward and Sophie Kasakove
title: Nearly all power has been restored in New Orleans, where at least 10 people died of excess heat after Ida.
description: The progress comes amid a rising death toll from the hurricane. Follow here for news on extreme weather in the U.S. and around the world.
content: With the vast majority of lights now on in New Orleans, city officials on Thursday were prepared for the next phase in navigating the aftermath of Hurricane Ida: recovery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Terry Brennan, a Notre Dame Football Coach at 25, Dies at 93
description: One of Frank Leahy’s Lads as a player on national championship teams, he succeeded his mentor but was fired at 30.
content: Terry Brennan was one of Leahy’s Lads, the elusive runners, strong-armed passers and muscular linemen who propelled Notre Dame to four national football championships under Coach Frank Leahy in the 1940s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: Take a ’90s nostalgia trip, sample some Korean cold noodles, or dig into the seamy back story of the leggings company LulaRoe.
content: Every Monday and Friday, Margaret offers hyper-specific viewing recommendations in our Watching newsletter. Read her latest picks below, and sign up for Watching here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Dings and Pings
description: What do you think this GIF is saying?
content: What do you think this GIF is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘The Capote Tapes’ Review: New Narratives and Unanswered Prayers
description: This documentary adds some material to the tragic tale of a great American writer, but also teases at what it can’t deliver.
content: There’s some fascinating and provocative material in “The Capote Tapes” that is diluted by the director Ebs Burnough’s insistence on teasing a question that, arguably, has a self-evident answer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anne Barnard
title: New York City’s rats felt the effects of Ida, too.
description: A surge of water that coursed through streets, pipes and basements likely drowned thousands of rats and disrupted their habitats, scientists say.
content: Nanaki Singh was walking home last week, hours after the remnants of Hurricane Ida turned many intersections in the Brooklyn neighborhood of East Williamsburg into knee-deep ponds, when he noticed a dead rat lying smack in the middle of the sidewalk. And another. And then another.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: What the Texas Abortion Law Means for California
description: Exploring the future of abortion access in the state.
content: The near-total ban on abortions in Texas that began last week has reverberated across the nation, with abortion rights advocates fearful of what’s to come as lawmakers in some states pledge to follow suit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: What to Know About the Sexual Misconduct Lawsuits Against Deshaun Watson
description: Twenty-two women have filed civil lawsuits in Texas accusing the quarterback of a pattern of coercive and lewd behavior.
content: Houston Texans quarterback Deshaun Watson is the subject of 22 civil suits filed in March and April which accuse him of coercive and lewd sexual behavior, with two that allege sexual assault. He has not been charged criminally and his lawyer has denied the accusations. Here’s where the cases stand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Canada’s Felix Auger-Aliassime and Leylah Fernandez Arrive at U.S. Open
description: The semifinalists are part of a new wave of Canadian tennis stars who are changing the image of the game in their country and reflecting its increased diversity.
content: Canada’s tennis success story continues to add chapters at breakneck pace with Felix Auger-Aliassime and Leylah Fernandez having advanced to the semifinals of the U.S. Open for the first time in their short careers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Lordi, David Leggett and Shadi Al-Atallah
title: The Black Recovery Stories Speaking to Individual and Collective Wellness
description: Long sidelined, these narratives are ascendant in the culture, and offer an elastic yet demanding view of what it might take for Americans — and their nation — to heal.
content: FOR ALL THAT was emotionally sobering about the last year, it was literally sobering, too. Many Americans, drinking more than ever during Covid-19 lockdowns and with plenty of time to reflect on it, began to wonder if alcohol was more hindrance than help. The question had been popularized by the sober-curious movement, based on a term coined by the British author Ruby Warrington, and supported by online recovery programs such as Tempest, founded in 2014. But it became especially acute as the incoherent national response to the Covid-19 pandemic conspired with a failing health care system to prove once again that the state could not be trusted to ensure its citizens’ wellness. This was particularly true, the reanimated Black Lives Matter movement announced, when those citizens were brown or Black.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Greenhouse
title: God Has No Place in Supreme Court Opinions
description: Republican officeholders are no longer coy about their religion-driven mission to stop abortion.
content: One hundred fifty years ago, a woman named Myra Bradwell brought a Supreme Court case claiming a constitutional right to be admitted to the Illinois bar. She had passed the state’s bar exam with high honors, but the Illinois Supreme Court refused her application, saying that when the State Legislature gave the court the power to grant law licenses, “it was with not the slightest expectation that this privilege would be extended to women.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Overlooked No More: Sinn Sisamouth, ‘King’ of Cambodian Pop Music
description: He and his singing partner, Ros Serey Sothea, drew from a wide range of Western and local influences. They disappeared after the Khmer Rouge seized power in 1975.
content: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi and Winston Choi-Schagrin
title: California Aims to Ban Recycling Symbols on Things That Aren’t Recyclable
description: The well-known three-arrows symbol doesn’t necessarily mean that a product is actually recyclable. A new bill would limit the products allowed to feature the mark.
content: The triangular “chasing arrows” recycling symbol is everywhere: On disposable cups. On shower curtains. On children’s toys.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: As a Daytime Host, Kelly Clarkson Has No Fear of Being Vocal
description: After its first two seasons were disrupted by the pandemic, “The Kelly Clarkson Show” has big expectations to fulfill. But its host is ready to come back better and, yes, stronger.
content: Kelly Clarkson had just come striding through an aisle of the Appel Room one afternoon in late August, accompanied by Kristin Chenoweth and a troupe of dancers as they sang the final bars of the uplifting Imagine Dragons ballad “On Top of the World.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adrienne Raphel
title: What Has One Eye and 1,200 Heads? An Old English Riddle, That’s What!
description: Riddles are as old as the English language and, as Adrienne Raphel explains, can tell us a lot about Anglo-Saxon culture — as long as we are able to solve them.
content: There’s a certain state of mind I call crossword brain: It’s both intuitive and counterintuitive, knowing when to turn away from the seemingly obvious solution, but also knowing when to trust your instincts and go with the answer that feels good. Crossword brain requires you to bend and sometimes entirely break the way you think you should make connections. Crosswords tug all sides of your mind, requiring you to dart from straightforward definitions to narrative logic to free association to bad dad puns, all in the same space.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe
title: Texas forbids political ‘censorship’ by social media companies.
description: Conservative states have increasingly targeted the ways that Silicon Valley companies police their platforms.
content: The governor of Texas signed a bill on Thursday banning social media platforms from removing posts because of the political views expressed in them, a measure that is likely to draw significant legal scrutiny after a similar law was blocked by a judge in Florida.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Kerr
title: 7 True Stories From Virtual School
description: Teachers, administrators and service providers talk about what remote teaching is really like.
content: Teachers started reporting that students were in class on Zoom while, for example, moving boxes at a warehouse. The norm was that the camera be on, but especially as time went on, the kids often had it pointed at the ceiling. Teachers could tell when kids were at work because it’s a higher ceiling than their bedrooms’.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Murphy
title: Qantas becomes one of the first airlines to require that international passengers be vaccinated.
description: The chief executive of the airline’s parent company said he hoped the policy would be in place “by Christmas."
content: Qantas, Australia’s largest airline, will require that all passengers on international flights are vaccinated against the coronavirus when it restarts worldwide operations in December, its chief executive said Wednesday, making it one of the first airlines in the world to require proof of vaccination for everyone on board.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill P. Capuzzo and Anne Mancuso
title: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
description: This week’s properties are a five-bedroom in White Plains, N.Y., and a four-bedroom in Holmdel, N.J.
content: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Goldstein
title: L.A. is set to become the first major U.S. school district to require vaccinations for students.
description: The Board of Education is expected to pass the measure in a vote on Thursday.
content: Los Angeles is poised to become the first major school district in the United States to mandate coronavirus vaccines for students 12 and older who are attending class in person.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia and Cora Engelbrecht
title: Fire at North Macedonia Covid Hospital Kills at Least 14
description: All were coronavirus patients being treated at a temporary hospital when the fire broke out. Its origins are being investigated.
content: A fire at a temporary coronavirus hospital in North Macedonia has left at least 14 people dead, the country’s health minister said, the latest in a series of blazes at hospitals around the world where people with Covid-19 were being treated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Was That Bunt Weird or Is Your Manager Mike Matheny?
description: A treasure trove of sortable statistics for managers gives fans the ability to track their team’s tendencies on things like stolen bases, intentional walks, ejections and, yes, bunts.
content: Baseball is a sport of numbers: 762 home runs, 511 wins, a 56-game hitting streak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Russia and Belarus Inch Closer to a Full-Blown Merger
description: In their sixth meeting in less than a year, the countries’ presidents agreed to deepen economic ties, leaving tougher political questions for later.
content: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia threw his embattled, authoritarian ally in Belarus a fresh lifeline on Thursday, pledging cheap natural gas and more than $600 million in new loans as part of a push to more closely integrate the post-Soviet neighbors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: The European Central Bank will slow its crisis-era bond buying.
description: The central bank also slightly raised its forecasts for inflation and economic growth.
content: The European Central Bank said on Thursday that it would slow down its pandemic-era bond-buying program, one of the main tools it has used to support the eurozone economy through lockdowns, citing “favorable financing conditions” and the inflation outlook.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Casey Mink
title: How a TV Ad Enticed Broadway Crowds Right After 9/11
description: Rudy Giuliani was meant to appear; Elaine Stritch arrived just in time. Recalling the “I Love New York” spot that helped dispel the fear in Times Square.
content: Following the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, Broadway suspended performances for just two days, reopening on Sept. 13, 2001. But audiences were hesitant to return, and many shows performed to near-empty houses for weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: A.I. Can Now Write Its Own Computer Code. That’s Good News for Humans.
description: A new technology called Codex generates programs in 12 coding languages and even translates between them. But it is not a threat to professional programmers.
content: As soon as Tom Smith got his hands on Codex — a new artificial intelligence technology that writes its own computer programs — he gave it a job interview.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Democrats Want a ‘Climate Corps.’ They Just Can’t Agree How to Create It.
description: Styled after the 1930s Civilian Conservation Corps, the program would put young people to work helping protect communities from climate disasters.
content: WASHINGTON — Democrats aim to pour tens of billions of dollars into a New Deal-style program that would hire young people to work on projects to protect communities and the environment from disasters that are growing more destructive due to climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: As Courts Reopen, Divorce Filings Are on the Rise
description: Whether the pandemic caused new problems or amplified old ones, divorce cases have family lawyers and judges busier than ever.
content: According to figures from the Superior Court of California, divorce filings are up significantly in Los Angeles over the last five months, as compared with the same period in 2020. And some lawyers and relationship experts say that divorce filings in New York and other states are also on the rise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Hickley
title: A Vermeer Restoration Reveals a God of Desire
description: An image of Cupid was covered over in “Girl Reading a Letter at an Open Window” for nearly 300 years. Now that he’s back on show, the famous painting looks quite different.
content: DRESDEN, Germany — After nearly three centuries behind a layer of paint, a naked Cupid has surfaced in one of the world’s best-loved artworks, drastically altering the background of a quiet interior scene.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Africa’s C.D.C. director urges wealthy nations to forego Covid vaccine boosters and donate them instead.
description: The World Health Organization asked wealthy countries to hold off on administering booster shots for healthy patients until at least the end of the year as a way of enabling every country to vaccinate at least 40 percent of their populations.
content: The decision by some rich nations to offer booster shots will hinder coronavirus vaccine access for low-income countries, the director of the Africa Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said on Thursday, arguing there is no conclusive evidence healthy people who are not immunocompromised need an extra shot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Heinrich
title: Art Fairs Come Blazing Back, Precarious but Defiant
description: New and overlooked artists shine at the Armory Show, New York’s largest in-person fair since the pandemic, and other shows across the city.
content: Even before Covid, the art world was changing rapidly. Sales that used to happen in New York or Basel, via hushed conversation, now happen through Instagram all over the world. Large galleries are merging to keep up with mega-galleries, while small galleries, somehow, keep multiplying.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: Russia Influences Hackers but Stops Short of Directing Them, Report Says
description: The arrangement allows the Russian government some plausible deniability for attacks, researchers found.
content: WASHINGTON — Moscow’s intelligence services have influence over Russian criminal ransomware groups and broad insight into their activities, but they do not control the organizations’ targets, according to a report released on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Lakin
title: A Designer Who Starts By Building Dollhouse-Like Maquettes
description: In his studio in Manhattan’s Chinatown, Giancarlo Valle dreams up furniture and rooms with a palpable sense of playfulness.
content: Designers often use the word “storytelling,” which can be a polite way of saying nothing. But Giancarlo Valle means it more specifically, as in a fairy tale. Valle, who creates soft, pared-down interiors and things to fill them, practices a strain of modernism dosed with whimsy — squat, oblong tables with mosaic tiled tops that resemble tortoise shells; stubby tearoom chairs upholstered in nubby chenille that recall the bottom half of a faun; velvet couches the color of tree bark that wind on for longer than would seem strictly necessary, all of which would look at home in a stylish storybook cottage, possibly one tucked within an enchanted forest. So it can be surprising to learn that Valle, 39, trained as an architect, a discipline that demands icy rigor, and worked for a number of years for some of the field’s most influential practitioners, including the firms SHoP and Snøhetta. In many ways, his own practice, which he started in 2016, is an effort to unlearn architecture’s cool remove, with which he grew disillusioned, in favor of something warmer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Martha Schwendener
title: Still Independent, and Still Exceptional
description: Let your fall re-entry begin at the Independent Art Fair in Manhattan, which features painting, photography and the pioneers of net art.
content: Coming up in the ’90s, “independent” (often shortened to “indie”) signaled culture that was maverick, authentic and relatively low budget. It meant movies that weren’t Hollywood-blockbuster types and music not released on corporate record labels. And while art didn’t necessarily follow the same ethos, or economic model, the Independent Art Fair, founded by fellow Gen-Xers Elizabeth Dee and Matthew Higgs, kind of felt like it did.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Dobbs
title: The Runty Prehistoric Mammals That Outlasted the Dinosaurs
description: In “Beasts Before Us,” the paleontologist Elsa Panciroli puts a spotlight on the small mammals that might have been our most important ancestors.
content: BEASTS BEFORE USThe Untold Story of Mammal Origins and EvolutionBy Elsa Panciroli
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: Elizabeth Warren asks Amazon to ‘stop peddling misinformation about Covid vaccines and treatments.’
description: In a letter addressed to Amazon’s chief executive, the Massachusetts senator asserted that the company’s search algorithm promotes books riddled with falsehoods about the pandemic.
content: Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusets sent a letter to Amazon this week demanding the company do more to stop “peddling misinformation about Covid-19 vaccines and treatments” through dubious products sold on the site.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: Impersonation? Yes. But With the Right Star, Something Richer.
description: In new musicals about Princess Diana, Cary Grant and Michael Jackson actors get a chance to embody icons while spotlighting their individual talents.
content: Just before the pandemic I ambivalently attended a performance of “Tina: The Tina Turner Musical.” I knew some Tina Turner songs, and I was vaguely aware of her marriage to the abusive Ike Turner. I was only barely acquainted with her global celebrity, and skeptical about the depth a biographical jukebox musical could offer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Li Yuan
title: ‘Reversing Gears’: China Increasingly Rejects English, and the World
description: A movement against Western influence threatens to close off a nation that succeeded in part by welcoming new ideas.
content: As a student at Peking University law school in 1978, Li Keqiang kept both pockets of his jacket stuffed with handwritten paper slips. An English word was written on one side, a former classmate recalled, and the matching Chinese version was written on the other.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal
title: Covid has disrupted learning for more than 400 million children in South Asia, the U.N. says.
description: A UNICEF report warned that the pandemic had forced a premature transition to remote learning in a region where many lack reliable internet access.
content: The pandemic is causing lasting damage to the education of children across South Asia, more than 400 million of whom are still facing school closures and limited access to remote learning, the United Nations said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Roth
title: Milkweed Butterflies Are More Murderous Than They Look
description: This behavior by the fluttering insects was so unusual that scientists had to invent a new word to describe it.
content: Butterflies seem gentle as they flutter from plant to plant. But some may be more murderous than you imagine. Naturalists recently witnessed several species of milkweed butterfly harassing, subduing and subsequently feeding on milkweed caterpillars, presumably to get their fill of toxic alkaloids inside the larvae.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Goldstein
title: Los Angeles Mandates Vaccines for Students 12 and Older
description: The decision by the second-largest school district in the country will increase safety in the classroom, but is likely to draw legal challenges.
content: Los Angeles is the first major school district in the United States to mandate coronavirus vaccines for students 12 and older who are attending class in person.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Carey
title: Men Fall Behind in College Enrollment. Women Still Play Catch-Up at Work.
description: Women are overrepresented in low-paying professions that require college credentials.
content: The coronavirus upended the lives of millions of college students. The Wall Street Journal reported this week that men have been hit particularly hard — accounting for roughly three-fourths of pandemic-driven dropouts — and depicted an accelerating crisis in male enrollment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric A. Taub
title: Building a More Sustainable Car, From Headlamp to Tailpipe
description: Vehicle makers shy away from traditional materials that are hard to recycle, like leather and plastics, and look to repurpose alternatives that still convey quality.
content: In the 1970s, Chrysler’s TV commercials played up its vehicles’ “rich Corinthian leather.” That meaningless phrase, dreamed up by marketers and cooed by the actor Ricardo Montalbán, became emblematic of what defined a luxury vehicle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Here’s What the Texas Abortion Law Says
description: We took an up-close look at the text of S.B. 8, which bans almost all abortions in Texas and delegates enforcement responsibility to citizens.
content: A new Texas law that the Supreme Court did not block last week has made abortion functionally illegal in the state. Several other states have tried over the years to limit or ban abortions before fetal viability but have not managed to maneuver past the courts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac
title: Smart Glasses Made Google Look Dumb. Now Facebook Is Giving Them a Try.
description: The company has teamed up with Ray-Ban to create glasses that can take photos, record video, answer phone calls and play podcasts.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Last Saturday, after a three-mile hike through the Presidio, I stood in a throng of tourists looking at the Golden Gate Bridge. As the crowd snapped photos of the landmark, I decided to join in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aida Alami and Nicholas Casey
title: Islamists See Big Losses in Moroccan Parliamentary Elections
description: The moderate Justice and Development Party may have lost control of Parliament, according to early results, in the latest defeat for Islamists in the region.
content: Morocco’s moderate Islamist party suffered major losses in parliamentary elections on Wednesday, a stinging setback in one of the last countries where Islamists had risen to power after the Arab Spring protests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘The Alpinist’ Review: Dizzying Heights
description: This documentary tries to shed light on the attitude of a Canadian rock climber it describes as “elusive.”
content: In a podcast excerpted at the start of “The Alpinist,” the rock climber Alex Honnold, from the Oscar-winning documentary “Free Solo,” is asked to name a climber who impresses him. He cites Marc-André Leclerc, a Canadian whom Honnold says takes on some of the sport’s most difficult challenges in “such a pure style.” Honnold’s remarks suggest Leclerc would happily ascend in obscurity, keeping his accomplishments between him and the mountains.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers and Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Biden Mandates Vaccines for Workers, Saying, ‘Our Patience Is Wearing Thin’
description: Initially reluctant to enact mandates, the president is now moving aggressively to require vaccination as the Delta variant races across the country.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Thursday used the full force of his presidency to push two-thirds of American workers to be vaccinated against the coronavirus, reaching into the private sector to mandate that all companies with more than 100 workers require vaccination or weekly testing.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 12 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: War and its aftermath figure prominently in our recommended titles this week, from Andrew Bacevich’s critique of American foreign policy (“After the Apocalypse”) to two books about the 20-year fight in Afghanistan (Carter Malkasian’s “The American War in Afghanistan” and Craig Whitlock’s “The Afghanistan Papers”) to Robert S. Levine’s study of Andrew Johnson’s role in the immediate wake of the Civil War (“The Failed Promise”). Meanwhile, Algeria’s war for independence from France provides the backdrop to Leila Slimani’s new novel, “In the Country of Others” — it’s subtitled “War, War, War” — which is based on her grandmother’s experiences during that conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Shapiro
title: How the Mayor’s Big Decision Could Upend N.Y.C. School Admissions
description: New York City’s highly competitive gifted and talented programs could be overhauled in one of the last major policy moves from Mayor Bill de Blasio.
content: Shortly after he took office eight years ago, Mayor Bill de Blasio vowed to tackle inequality in New York City’s public schools. But as the mayor enters his final months in office, the city’s schools remain among the most racially segregated in America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon
title: Israel will reopen to small groups of vaccinated tourists after the High Holy Days.
description: Visits from organized groups of vaccinated tourists will be allowed after Yom Kippur, the holiest day of the Jewish year, the government said.
content: Israel plans to allow visits from organized groups of vaccinated tourists after Yom Kippur, the holiest day of the Jewish year, taking a step toward reopening to the world even as health officials record thousands of new coronavirus infections daily.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: When Was the First U.S. Covid Death? C.D.C. Investigates 4 Early Cases
description: The deaths, spread out across four states in January 2020, have become part of a scattershot collection of clues about the virus’s early spread.
content: Late last year, the federal government’s chief statistician on death received word about a tantalizing discovery: Someone had died from Covid-19 in January 2020, a death certificate said, a revelation that would have sped up the timeline of the virus’s spread in the United States by several weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: Democrats Unveil Details of Sweeping Climate Change Spending Plan
description: At the heart of a budget bill is a powerful mechanism that would cut the country’s greenhouse gas emissions, which are fueling climate change.
content: WASHINGTON — The coming weeks on Capitol Hill will be crucial to President Biden’s climate agenda, including whether the president can credibly make the case to the rest of the world that the United States will meet his promise to drastically reduce emissions that are warming the planet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman and Emily Cochrane
title: House panels begin writing the $3.5 trillion social policy and climate bill.
description: Five committees started drafting the components of Democrats’ far-reaching legislation in an arduous process that could take several days.
content: Five House committees on Thursday began formally drafting their pieces of Democrats’ far-reaching social policy and climate change bill that would spend as much as $3.5 trillion over the next decade — and raise as much in taxes and other revenue boosters — to reweave the social safety net and move the country away from fossil fuels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Fire Music’ Review: An Impassioned Case for Free Jazz
description: The beautiful souls that created free jazz — including Ornette Coleman, Cecil Taylor, Don Cherry and Carla Bley — light up this new documentary from Tom Surgal.
content: One default reaction to the musical form called “free jazz” — Ornette Coleman’s phrase for this improvised, experimental style of jazz — has long been that it’s “not music.” This concise but cogent documentary directed by Tom Surgal is crammed with exhilarating sounds, moving reminiscences and stimulating arguments that it is not just music, but vital music.
source.name: The New York Times

description: The trove, which is going on sale because of a court order, includes pieces by Cy Twombly, Gerhard Richter and Andy Warhol, and is valued at more than $600 million.
content: With major pieces by artists like Andy Warhol, Cy Twombly, Gerhard Richter and Mark Rothko, the Macklowe Collection will be sold at Sotheby’s with an estimated total value of more than $600 million, the auction house announced on Thursday, the highest estimate on a collection to come to auction.

author: By Lisa Kennedy
title: ‘Fauci’ Review: The First Pandemic That Shaped the Good Doc
description: This documentary underscores the hard-fought lessons the immunologist learned during the AIDS pandemic. Many shape his resolve now.
content: In their sympathetic portrait “Fauci,” John Hoffman and Janet Tobias introduce Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, the director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, with a split-screen. On one side, the man who has been the face of the nation’s Covid-19 response leaves his home with a security detail. Next to this gray-haired public health figure unspools news footage of a younger Dr. Fauci walking up stairs to begin, as a reporter states, “his 12-hour day.” At the time, he was leading the nation’s H.I.V./AIDS response.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Texas’ Abortion Law Should Force America to Change Its Ways
description: A law preserving the life of a human being at any stage can be considered “extreme” only within a distorted social context.
content: Abortion is a failure for every woman and her unborn child — a failure of love, justice and mercy. Texas’ new abortion law is far from perfect, but I hope it can move us closer to these ideals.

author: By Peter Kujawinski
title: Air Travel After 9/11: Just Get Through It
description: Before the terrorist attacks, airplane passengers weren’t seen as security risks, and flying was an enjoyable extension of the vacation experience — not something merely to anxiously endure.
content: To understand how very different the experience of flying was before Sep. 11, 2001, consider this story from Felix Hernandez about ordering pizza. In 1999, Mr. Hernandez was the pilot on a Trans World Airlines flight from New York’s Kennedy International Airport to Chicago that was nearing takeoff when it was called back because of weather. The gate that the Boeing 727 had left from was already filled, so Mr. Hernandez was told to taxi the plane to a parking area to wait out the delay.
